feed.title: [BIP Proposal] Soft Fork Compromise on op_return to Resolve Current Bitcoin Controversies

entry.title: [BIP Proposal] Soft Fork Compromise on op_return to Resolve Current Bitcoin Controversies
entry.summary:
The discussion revolves around the challenges and potential solutions concerning spam on the Bitcoin blockchain, specifically focusing on the use of OP_RETURN versus other mechanisms by spammers. A significant issue highlighted is that nearly half of the Unspent Transaction Outputs (UTXOs) are currently considered spam, posing a considerable expense for node runners. The relatively low cost of block space contributes to this problem, making it easy for spammers to waste space.
OP_RETURN, a mechanism intended for inserting arbitrary data into transactions without affecting the UTXO set, has limitations in relaying data over 83 bytes. This limitation makes OP_PUSH (inscriptions) a more attractive option for spammers. In light of these concerns, the suggestion of implementing a soft fork that includes reducing block size and introducing UTXO-sharing opcodes, like CTV (CHECKTEMPLATEVERIFY), is put forward as a solution.
Reducing the block size and encouraging UTXO sharing could benefit both node operators and the decentralization of the network. Smaller blocks would deter spammers due to the increased costs and reduced efficiency for spamming activities, while UTXO sharing would not assist spammers but instead promote more efficient use of resources among legitimate users. The conversation acknowledges that if spammers opt to store data externally and use Bitcoin merely as a representation of ownership, it might be impossible to eliminate spam entirely. However, the proposed changes aim to significantly reduce the presence of spam on the blockchain itself.
